intro: Boswellia ameero, commonly known as Indian frankincense, is a small evergreen tree native to the dry regions of southern India. It belongs to the Burseraceae family and is characterized by its aromatic resinous sap, which is harvested for its medicinal and aromatic properties. The plant produces a gum resin known as olibanum, which has been used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects. Its leaves are alternate, leathery, and have a distinctive scent, while its flowers are yellow and clustered. Boswellia ameero thrives in arid and semi-arid climates, requiring minimal water and well-drained soil.
